guides.title: Bootstrap Guide
guides.description: A detailed guide on Bootstrap, the most used CSS framework for creating responsive and modern websites.

topics.description:
Bootstrap is an open-source framework created by Twitter with the aim of simplifying the development of responsive and accessible user interfaces.

Why use Bootstrap?

  • Easy to use: Includes ready-to-use CSS classes that simplify layout creation and graphical components.
  • Responsive Design: Automatically adapts layouts to different devices, ensuring an optimal user experience on mobile, tablets, and desktops.
  • Cross-browser compatibility: Supports all modern browsers.
  • Predefined components: Includes elements like navbar, modals, forms, cards, and many others.
  • JavaScript support: Offers advanced functionalities without the need for external libraries.

How Bootstrap Works?

Bootstrap is based on a modular system that includes a flexible grid for dynamic layouts and a series of CSS and JavaScript components for interactive elements.

Conclusion

Bootstrap is an essential tool for any developer looking to create modern, performant, and responsive websites without having to write complex CSS code.

Fundamentals of HTML Tags and Attributes

HTML uses tags to structure the content of a web page. Each tag has a specific purpose and can include attributes to define its behavior or appearance.

Most common tags:

  • <h1>...</h1>: Headings from h1 to h6 for titles of different sizes.
  • <p>...</p>: Paragraphs of text.
  • <a href='URL'>Link</a>: Hypertext links.
  • <img src='image.jpg' alt='Description'>: Insert images.
  • <div>...</div>: Containers for layouts and complex structures.

Important attributes:

  • id: Unique identifier for an element.
  • class: Defines a CSS class for styling.
  • alt: Alternative text for images.
  • href: Destination address for links.

guides.title: Git Guide
guides.description: Learn how to use Git, the most popular version control system among developers, to manage your projects.

topics.topic: What is Git and why use it?
topics.description:
What is Git?

Git is a distributed version control system created by Linus Torvalds in 2005. It's designed to efficiently manage code development, allowing multiple developers to work simultaneously without conflicts.

Why use Git?

  • Change history: Every modification to the code is tracked, allowing the restoration of previous versions if necessary.
  • Collaboration: Multiple developers can work on the same project at the same time without overwriting each other's work.
  • Speed and reliability: Being a distributed system, every copy of a repository contains the entire history, improving data security.
  • Branching and merging: Allows creating separate development branches to test new functionalities and merge them later.

Installing Git

Git is available for Windows, macOS, and Linux. To install it, follow these steps:

  • Windows: Download the installer from the official website git-scm.com and follow the guided instructions.
  • macOS: Install it with Homebrew by running brew install git.
  • Linux: Use the command sudo apt install git on Debian/Ubuntu or sudo dnf install git on Fedora.

Configuring Git

After installation, it's necessary to configure your username and email to track changes:

git config --global user.name 'YourName' git config --global user.email 'youremail@example.com'

You can verify the configuration by running:

git config --list

guides.title: HTML and CSS Guide
guides.description: A comprehensive guide to learn the basics of HTML and CSS, the fundamental building blocks of web design.

topics.description:
Structure of an HTML Page

An HTML file is composed of a well-defined structure that organizes the content of a web page. Every HTML document starts with a DOCTYPE declaration to indicate the browser about the version of HTML in use.

Basic structure:

<!DOCTYPE html> <html lang='en'> <head> <meta charset='UTF-8'> <meta name='viewport' content='width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0'> <title>Page Title</title> </head> <body> <h1>Welcome to the World of HTML</h1> <p>This is an example paragraph.</p> </body> </html>

Every HTML page is divided into two main sections: the head, which contains metadata and links to style sheets and scripts, and the body, which contains the visible content of the page.

guides.title: TypeScript Guide
guides.description: An introduction to TypeScript, a superset of JavaScript that improves type management and code control.

topics.description:
Why Use TypeScript?

TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript developed by Microsoft that adds support for static types, improving the readability, maintainability, and security of the code. Here are some key advantages:

  • Error prevention: Thanks to static types, TypeScript helps avoid common coding errors.
  • Autocomplete and IntelliSense: Provides intelligent suggestions and real-time documentation.
  • Safe refactoring: Enhances the ability to modify code without introducing bugs.
  • Compatibility with JavaScript: Can be used on any existing JavaScript codebase.
  • Advanced support for ES6+: Includes modern functionalities like async/await, destructuring, and ES6+ modules.

guides.title: SQL Guide
guides.description: Learn SQL, the essential language for managing relational databases.

topics.description:
Introduction to Relational Databases

SQL (Structured Query Language) is a programming language used to manage and query relational databases. Relational databases organize data into tables connected through primary and foreign keys.

Why use a relational database?

  • Organized structure: Data is stored in tables with rows and columns.
  • Referential integrity: Relationships between tables ensure data coherence.
  • Efficiency: SQL allows for quickly retrieving, updating, and managing large amounts of data.

Main Relational Databases

Among the most used are: MySQL, PostgreSQL, Microsoft SQL Server, Oracle, and SQLite.
